content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is simple, yet `k` an `n` instead of `n` and `k` make you think:D

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I thought it was combinations that were asked, but this is indeed the formula for permutations when permuting only part of the set which i did not know. This, potential overflows, and the n and k being named conterintuively makes it a good mental gymnastic.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is the easy problem if you known the formula of permutation and calculate the factorial.

I think you just give the answer to the problem inside the "input" section !

For me, it would be better to specify that the output is number of x-uplets distinct elements you can build from an ensemble of size y, without giving the formula (otherwise there is no challenge)...

By the way, it's actually not "permutations", but  "x-uplets of distinct elements", because "permutations" have the initial ensemble's size...

Finally, I think that notations "n" and "k" would be more convenient than "y" and "x"...

Goal
* Your statement does not define the problem clearly. Please revise as follows:

You are given [[x]] and [[y]], where [[x]] represents the number of objects to select from a set of [[y]] distinct objects. You must output the number of permutations, using this formula: [[y]]! / ([[y]] - [[x]])! .

Input
* There are two lines, not one. Please rewrite as follows:

<<Line 1>>: An integer [[x]] for the number of objects to select
<<Line 2>>: An integer [[y]] for the total number of objects

Output
* Please change "that the permutation results to" to "of permutations".

Constraints
* Please format all instances of "x" and "y" as [[variables]].

Game modes
* Suggest to disable Reverse mode.

Thanks.

This is not a maths challenge, so the formula should be given.

The player still has to know how to write the code to calculate factorials. And for languages other than Python, the last pair of test and validator is going to give the player a headache because of the large numbers. If not handled correctly, they can easily face an overflow.

Yes, it's an "easy" challenge after all...

I tried to solve this in C,C++,Java and JS, and I just had to use "long int" instead of "int" to calculate properly the factorial, no real headache...

Though I still think that "permutations" is not the good term to describe this problem, and that notations n and k would be more adapted !
